briefdescription.para: Cascade for IRQs 8–15 (used internally by PIC)
Local APIC timer vector (used instead of IRQ0 in APIC mode)
Mappings of hardware IRQ lines to remapped IDT interrupt vectors.

detaileddescription.para: IRQs are remapped to avoid conflicts with CPU exceptions (0–31). This enum provides named constants for common hardware IRQs, starting at interrupt vector 32.

memberdef.argsstring: (uint8_t n, isr_t handler, pci_dev_t device, void *opaque)
memberdef.name: register_interrupt_handler

briefdescription.para: Register an interrupt handler for a given ISR or IRQ line.

detaileddescription.para: This function attaches a handler to an interrupt vector n, allowing multiple devices to share the same IRQ line via a linked list of handlers. The handler will be invoked when the interrupt occurs, with the given opaque pointer passed back as context.

If the interrupt number n is 32 or higher, it is assumed to be an IRQ (as per the irq_number_t scheme), and the corresponding I/O APIC input line is unmasked automatically. This enables delivery of the IRQ to the local APIC once registered.

For IRQ sharing, you must provide the device field correctly so that handlers for multiple PCI devices on the same line can be tracked and dispatched safely. This is a requirement of shared interrupt delivery.

parameterdescription.para: Interrupt number - 0–31 are reserved ISRs; 32+ are IRQs.
Function pointer to the interrupt handler.
For PCI devices, specify the device node responsible. Used to manage IRQ sharing.
A user-defined pointer passed to the handler on invocation.

simplesect.para: false if memory allocation failed or registration was unsuccessful; true otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Global entry point for CPU exceptions and software ISRs (ISR < 32).

detaileddescription.para: This function is the common handler for processor-generated exceptions (such as divide-by-zero, page faults, general protection faults, etc.) and any custom software ISRs within the reserved range 0–31.
It is invoked directly from the IDT when an exception occurs. The errorcode parameter is provided by the CPU and may contain relevant fault information depending on the exception type.

parameterdescription.para: The associated CPU-generated error code (or zero if unused).

briefdescription.para: Global entry point for hardware IRQs (ISR ≥ 32, remapped).

detaileddescription.para: This function is invoked by the interrupt dispatcher when a hardware interrupt request (IRQ) occurs. The ISR number corresponds to the remapped IRQ vector, typically starting at 32 (e.g., IRQ0 = ISR32).
These interrupts originate from external devices and are routed through the IOAPIC to the local APIC. All hardware IRQs provide an error code of zero by convention.

briefdescription.para: Deregister an interrupt handler for a specific ISR or IRQ.

detaileddescription.para: Removes the first matching handler function for the given interrupt vector. If the interrupt vector corresponds to an IRQ (n ≥ 32) and no more handlers remain, the interrupt is masked again using the IOAPIC.

parameterdescription.para: The interrupt vector number (0–255). Values ≥ 32 represent IRQs.

simplesect.para: true if the handler was found and removed, false if not found.

briefdescription.para: Remap legacy IRQs 0–23 to IOAPIC redirection entries.

detaileddescription.para: This function configures the IOAPIC to handle all standard IRQs (0 through 23) by setting up redirection table entries with appropriate vector numbers, polarity, and trigger modes. All entries are initially remapped in a masked (disabled) state to prevent spurious interrupts.
The actual unmasking of IRQs should be done later by calling ioapic_mask_set(gsi, false) once an appropriate handler is installed. Calling register_interrupt_handler() does this automatically.
